awd_titl_txt: The community ecology of viromes:  Virome assembly and pathogen transmission in a changing landscape
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging infectious diseases (EIDs) threaten global health and security, but when and where they will occur remains unfortunately hard to predict. In part, this may be because pathogens are usually studied in isolation. An alternative approach is to consider emerging pathogens as members of an ecological community of interacting microbes. The community ecology of viruses co-occurring in hosts -- the virome -- has yet to be explored as an ecological community even though viruses are known to be important emerging disease agents. The research supported by this award will address this deficiency by focusing on the viromes living inside two widespread species that live in close association with humans: the white footed mouse (Peromyscus leucopus) and the blacklegged tick (Ixodes scapularis).  Blacklegged ticks feed abundantly on white-footed mice, and the two species freely exchange microbes during the lengthy blood meals.  By exploring how the viromes of these two species are assembled and how they interact and flow between mice and ticks, the proposed research will reveal how viromes shape transmission of existing and potential pathogens. The research will be carried out in the northeast corridor of the United States, an area known to be an excellent location for studying virus emergence and the role played by white-footed mice and blacklegged ticks in the transmission of zoonotic pathogens (those transmitted from vertebrate animals to humans).  White-footed mice and blacklegged ticks serve as reservoir host and vector, respectively, of many emerging diseases of humans, including Lyme disease. Pilot studies have revealed that these same two species also harbor a community of previously undescribed viruses that may emerge as zoonotic diseases in the future. 

The researchers take an explicitly ecological approach to understanding viromes of reservoir and vector hosts. The researchers will: (1) characterize the viromes of both mouse and tick; (2) determine patterns of virome assembly throughout the lifetimes of both mouse and tick; (3) determine how virus communities affect the transmission of several important vector borne zoonotic pathogens; (4) identify whether viromes affect differences between individual mice and ticks in their abilities to transmit known and new pathogens; and (5) determine whether viromes and transmission probabilities change along with changing abundance of mice and between suburban/urban and more rural habitats. Data generated by each of these specific aims will be modeled using statistical (machine learning) algorithms, which accommodate diverse data types and apply a model-free analytical approach. By using complex and high-dimensional empirical data describing hosts, vectors, viromes, and their shared natural environments, these algorithms can achieve superior pattern detection  (such as virome composition) and improved ability to make useful predictions (such as what combinations of traits of vector viromes and mammal hosts best predict virus transmission).

por.por_cntn:
The community ecology of viromes in a changing landscape:

Virome assembly and transmission in white-footed mice and blacklegged ticks

We set out to better understand the virome of high-risk reservoirs and vectors in the densely populated woodlands of the Northeast United States.  The virome is the community of viruses that inhabit a host over the course of its lifetime. We also wanted to determine if this community of viruses might have functionality akin to that ascribed to the microbiome, which is the community of bacteria that inhabit a host over the course of its lifetime. In order to accomplish this, we first needed to describe the viruses in our system and we used deep metagenomic sequencing to do this.  Sequencing basically tells us the letters of the genetic code. With this data, we can use bioinformatic approaches to determine which bits belong to viruses, which are bacteria, and which are part of the host species. When we are lucky and we take good care of the samples, we occasionally get a whole genome which is all of the letters of the genetic code of a particular virus, in order!  Once we have that, we can compare it to the genetic code of all of the other known viruses (the relatives) and determine what type of parasite we have discovered.  

We chose black-legged ticks and white-footed mice as our study organisms because many emerging zoonotic infectious diseases arise from these two species. Indeed, Lyme Disease, anaplasma, babesia, as well as Powasson virus and deer tick virus have all only recently been discovered as human pathogens. With a list like that, it seems reasonable to expect more parasites might be coming for us! So we decided to capture and sequence a whole bunch of these ticks from across their geographic range at all times of year and during all three of their life stages (larvae, nymph and adult).  At least now we know the pool of pathogenic organisms that exist, and could potentially be the next emerging pathogen. We summarized our research effort and the findings of others in our paper entitled: The Ecology of New Constituents of the Tick Virome and Their Relevance to Public Health (https://www.mdpi.com/1999-4915/11/6/529/htm).

 Likewise, the white-footed mouse can transmit a number of zoonotic parasites to humans. These most notable are the hantaviruses which can cause considerable mortality in humans and transmit via inhalation of the aerosolized feces and urine of these mice. Mice harbor bacteria responsible for Lyme disease, anaplasmosis, tularemia, plague, bartonellosis, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever; protozoans responsible for babesiosis, giardiasis, toxoplasmosis, and cryptosporidiosis; and viruses responsible for lymphocytic choriomeningitis, and Powassan encephalitis and hantavirus pulmonary syndrome, to name a few more. White-footed mice and their sister species (Genus Peromyscus) are the rodents that commonly invade our houses and garages in suburban areas.  They are the ones filling your boots with cat food and making nests out of our riding lawnmower’s air filter. So not only are they risky species because they have so many demonstrated pathogens, but they also have ample opportunity to spread them to humans because they live right alongside of us…often unnoticed because they are as quiet as a mouse! We did the same thing with the sequencing of these rodents. We actually followed individual mice from birth through adulthood and collected blood, urine, skin, feces and saliva samples from them weekly. and we turned up around 40 different viruses! Some of the viruses we found are illustrated in Figure 2. One of these turned out to be a new virus capable of infecting humans! Although we know humans have been exposed to this virus, we do not yet know if it makes people sick. We do know that its closest relatives use ticks as vectors and have been implicated in causing febrile illness in humans in China. This novel virus is named Flavi-Like Segmented Virus US (FLSV-US) and we published a paper about it in Emerging Infectious Diseases (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7392405/).  

Most irionically, an emerging virus altered our plans at this point in our research plan. In order for me to be on campus, I needed to shift my work to SARS-2-CoV. This was easy for us and we began screening our small mammal species for exposure and active infections because we knew the previous SARS viruses spilled from humans into other animal species (i.e. cats and camels). I had also been seeking out white-tailed deer samples for FLSV testing and so we used those to show the deer were indeed positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA, indicating they had active infections. Work along these lines resulted in two papers in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, one in Scientific Reports and one in Viruses. The latter was the first demonstration of Omicron's spillover into wild species in the world.  

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2022
Modified by: Kurt Vandegrift
